questions.text: Which of the following investigation is best to assess stress fractures?
questions.solution:
• Investigation of choice in stress fracture is MRI.
  • IOC for bilateral stress fractures- Bone scan
  • MRI is highly  sensitive and can detect early bone stress injuries before they become full blown fractures.
  • X rays may not show a stress fracture until weeks after the onset of symptoms when bone healing and callus formation occurs.

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 7

questions.text: Which displacement from the list below is absent from Colle's fracture
questions.solution:
• Volar Tilt is not seen in Colle's fracture.
  • Colle's fracture is fracture at distal end of radius at the Cortico Cancellous junction 
  • It occurs due to fall on out stretched hands with extended wrists.
  • Displacement can result in a characteristic "dinner fork" deformity of the wrist.
  • In Colles' fracture, the volar tilt is usually maintained, and the dorsal displacement is the main characteristic feature.
  • The displacements seen in Colles fracture as follows -
  


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no112

questions.text: What is the best line of treatment for the X ray shown below?
questions.solution:
• The fracture displayed in the image is a transverse fracture of the patella .
  • Tension band wiring is the correct treatment option for this type of fracture.
  • Tension band wiring involves placing two Kirschner wires (K-wires) across the fracture site, with one wire placed above the fracture and the other below it.
  • A stainless steel wire is then wrapped around the K-wires and tightened to create a tension band.
  • This tension band converts the tensile forces that would otherwise be applied to the fracture site during knee extension into compression forces, which promote healing.
  •         

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 148

questions.text: What kind of fracture is depicted in the image?
questions.solution:
• In the given X-ray of proximal humerus fracture, there is a three-part fracture, which fits it into Neer's type III.
  • It is based on the location and number of fracture fragments
  • Neer Classification for Proximal humerus fractures is as follows
Type I • Minimally Displaced, one-part fracture, fracture lines involve 1-4 parts
Account for ~70-80% of all proximal humeral fractures

Type II • Two-part fracture, fracture lines involve 2-4 parts, one part is displaced (Anatomical neck)

Type III • Three-part fracture, fracture lines involve 3-4 parts, two parts are displaced (Surgical neck)

Type IV • Four-part fracture, fracture lines involve more than 4 parts & three parts are displaced (Greater tuberosity)

Type V • Lesser tuberosity fractures

Type VI • Fracture dislocations






Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 92

questions.text:
A 40 years old male fell on the outstretched hand with radial side pain and
tenderness in anatomical snuffbox and restriction of wrist movement.
Following is the X-ray image. Most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
•  X-ray that shows a transverse line in the scaphoid bone and a history of falling on an outstretched hard with radial side discomfort, soreness, and restriction of wrist movement is suggestive of a scaphoid fracture.
  • The scaphoid bone is located in the anatomical snuffbox and is commonly fractured when a person falls on an outstretched hand with radial deviation.
  • Clinical features- Tenderness at the anatomical snuff box.
  • Treatment- Cast in glass holding position

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 115

choices.text: Bilateral limb wound of >10 cm adequate soft tissue coverage in spite of extensive laceration, flaps, avulsion injury and regardless of size of wound
Bilateral limb wound of size >10 cm with extensive soft tissue damage and periosteal stripping
Wound between 1 and 10 cm with extensive soft tissue damage, flaps or avulsions

questions.text:
A patient with a history of RTA arrives at the emergency department.
The attending orthopaedic surgeon writes a IIIB for his both lower limb damage fractures.
Which of the following is the accurate Gustilo-Anderson classification?
questions.solution:
• The Gustilo-Anderson classification is used to classify open fractures where the bone is exposed to the outside environment due to a break in the skin.
  • The classification is based on the severity of the soft tissue injury, which is a major determinant of the prognosis and treatment of the fracture.
 
Type Characteristics
I Puncture wound < 1 cm
Minimal contamination
Minimal soft tissue damage
II Laceration > 1 cm but < 10 cm
Moderate soft tissue damage
Adequate bone coverage
Minimal comminution
III A Laceration > 10 cm
Extensive soft tissue damage
Adequate bone coverage
Segmental/severely comminuted fractures or heavily contaminated wounds
III B As a Gustilo type III A injury, but with periosteal stripping and bone exposure
III C Any open fracture with vascular injury requiring repair
  

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 21

questions.text: A patient was injured in a car accident and sustained a left knee injury. The dial test resulted in a positive result. What could be the source of the problem?
questions.solution:
•  
  • Dial test is used for checking posterolateral instability of the knee joint.
  • The posterolateral corner is a complex that includes that includes the lateral collateral ligament, popliteus tendon,  arcuate ligament, popliteofibular ligament, and the short lateral ligament
  • Tests for posterolateral instability include dial external (lateral) rotation (of tibia) test, external rotation recurvatum test, reverse pivot shift test of Jakob, Hassler and Staubli and posterolateral drawer test.
  • Dial Test / Tibial External (Lateral) Rotation Test With patient in supine or prone position, external rotation of tibia on the femur is measured at both 30° and 90° of knee flexion and compared with the opposite leg.

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 154

questions.text: As may be seen in the Knee X-ray below, an athlete has a fracture. How will you treat this fracture?
questions.solution:
• The given radiograph shows displaced patellar fracture which is managed by tension wire banding.
  • It works on the principle of converting distraction force from pull of quadriceps muscle into tension force. 
  • Tension wire banding is also performed for displaced olecranon fractures against distraction pull of triceps muscle. 
  • Undisplaced fractures of patella are managed conservatively by cylindrical cast. 
     
Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 148

questions.text: Which of the following promotes the production of calluses?
questions.solution:
• Small amount of motion ( micromovements ) and weight bearing at the fracture causes a soft callus to form leading on to secondary bone formation. It encourages vascular proliferation.
  • Depending on the stability of fixation and the underlying fracture pattern, weight bearing is started as early as possible to 'stimulate' fracture healing.
  • Some fixators incorporate a telescopic unit that allows 'dynamization'; this will convert the forces of weight-bearing into axial micro movement at the fracture site, thus promoting callus formation and accelerating bone union. 
  • Rigid immobilization, compression plating, and intraosseous nailing are techniques used to stabilize the broken bone ends and prevent excessive movement. While they are important for proper bone alignment and stability, they do not directly promote the formation of callus.

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 11,12,49

questions.text: An elderly female sustained Colle's fracture in her right hand, which was properly treated and cast was removed. After some weeks, she now complains of pain out of proportion and swelling with stiffness in the wrist with cyanosis discoloration and trophic changes in the fingers. X-ray of the hand revealed complete decalcification. She is most likely suffering from:
questions.solution:
Presence of severe pain out of proportion, stiffness in the wrist with cyanosis and trophic changes in fingers, weeks after injury and treatment with cast suggests a diagnosis of Complex Regional Pain Syndrome Type I (Reflex Sympathetic Dystrophy) also known as Sudeck's atrophy. It occurs due to Sympathetic nervous system dysfunction, in this case due to trauma. 
Its features include :-
1. Burning or electric-shock-like pain.
2. Skin tenderness.
3. Allodynia (sensitivity to touch).
4. Decreased range of motion in an affected area.
5. Changes in the skin over an affected area, such as inflammation, discoloration, and increased sweating.
6. Weakness in an affected area.
7. Osteoporosis, which may lead to fractures.
8. Swelling in an affected area.
9. Limited mobility.
10. Aesthetic deformities such as shortening of affected muscles, joint deformity, and clubbing.

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 51,52

questions.text: A 24 years old college student while playing hockey injured his right knee. This patient presents after 3 months with instability of knee joint in full extension without instability at 90 degree of flexion. The structure most commonly damaged is:
questions.solution:
• The postero-lateral bundle helps to resist hyperextension, anterior translation and rotation when the knee is in an extended position.
  • The posterolateral part of the ACL is the most commonly injured region of the ACL.
  • The fact that there is no instability at 90 degrees of flexion indicates that the ACL injury is likely limited to the posterolateral part of the ligament.
  • If the knee is hyperextended and internally rotated, the posterior lateral bundle is particularly susceptible to injury.
  • If this bundle is damaged, there is an increased range of motion in hyperextension and anterior translation at the knee joint when extended.
  • Therefore, postero-lateral bundle of anterior cruciate ligament is the most commonly damaged structure in above mentioned situation.

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 148,149

choices.text: Distal segment is dislocated anteriorly more than posterior
Cubitus valgus more common than cubitus varus during malunion

questions.text: Which of the following is true about supracondylar fracture of humerus?
questions.solution:
• Nerve injury related manifestations are transitory
  • Option 1. Posterior and not anterior dislocation is common for distal fragment in supracondylar humerus fracture
  • Option 2. Malunion causing cubitus varus is more common than valgus. Cubitus varus leads to gunstock deformity.
  • Option 4. Most common nerve injury in supracondylar humerus fracture is median nerve.
  • Supracondylar fracture of the humerus is a common type of elbow injury that occurs in children.
  • Nerve injury is a common complication of supracondylar fractures. The most commonly injured nerve is the median nerve, followed by the radial and ulnar nerves.
  • The nerve injury related manifestations can include numbness, tingling, weakness, and loss of sensation in the hand and fingers. However, these manifestations are usually temporary and resolve within a few weeks to months.


Reference: Textbook of Orthopedics by John Ebnezar, 5th Edition Pages 138-141

questions.text: The most serious complication of a pelvic fracture is:
questions.solution:
• Pelvic fractures can cause significant bleeding due to the large blood vessels that run through the pelvis.
  • The most serious complication of a pelvic fracture is hypovolemic shock. Pelvic fracture causes approximately 1L blood loss. 
  • Treatment -Stop the  bleeding, replacing lost blood with fluids, blood and blood products, and stabilizing the patient's condition. Pelvic Binder is recommended in hemodynamically unstable patients  as it reduces pelvic volume and controls bleeding {Contraindicated in open pelvic fractures.}

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 128

questions.text: In 2 years old child gallows traction is applied. Child is suffering from fracture of:
questions.solution:
• Gallow's traction is used for treatment of fracture shaft of femur, in infants and children <2 years of age.
  • Weight must not be >12 kgs.
  • Both the fractured and the normal femur are placed in skin traction and infant is suspended by these from a special frame.
  • The buttocks should be lifted just off the bed so that the weight of the body provides counter traction and the fracture is reduced.

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 143

questions.text: One should avoid using metal on metal articulation in:
questions.solution:
Metal-on-metal (MoM) articulation is generally avoided in young females for several reasons:

1. Metal Ion Release: MoM implants can release metal ions, such as cobalt and chromium, into the bloodstream due to wear over time. These ions can accumulate in tissues, potentially causing local soft tissue reactions (metallosis), inflammation, and pseudotumor formation. In young females, the long-term exposure to these ions is a significant concern, particularly given their longer life expectancy.

2. Reproductive Health Concerns- There are concerns about the effect of metal ions on fertility and pregnancy. Elevated levels of metal ions in the bloodstream may pose a theoretical risk to a developing fetus. This is especially important in younger women who may still want to bear children.

3. Higher Failure Rates: MoM implants have shown higher revision rates due to mechanical wear, loosening, and tissue reactions compared to other bearing surfaces like ceramic or polyethylene. Given the younger patient’s activity level and longer life expectancy, the risk of implant failure becomes more significant.

4. Increased Risk of Adverse Reactions: MoM implants are associated with adverse local tissue reactions (ALTRs) and osteolysis (bone loss), which can complicate future revision surgeries. Young females are likely to outlive their implants, and having these complications can make future revisions more complex.

Because of these risks, other materials like ceramic-on-ceramic or ceramic-on-polyethylene are generally preferred for young female patients.

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 341

questions.text: In patients with non-union, which of the following substances is used to promote bone formation?
questions.solution:
• Bone morphogenetic proteins are used for bone formation in patients with non-union.
  • BMPs are a group of growth factors that stimulate the differentiation of mesenchymal stem cells into osteoblasts.
  • BMPs have been shown to be effective in promoting bone formation in non-unions.

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 85

questions.text: 20-year-old patient has RTA with an injury to the left forearm. There is a brachial artery laceration of 3.5 cm seen. What is the preferred technique of repair in this case?
questions.solution:
• According to the given history, patient has a brachial artery laceration of 3.5 cm length.
  • Because of an injury of this length, end to end anastomosis is not possible. Vessel injuries that cannot be repaired by primary end to end technique will require an interposition graft.
  • The most desirable graft is an autologous great saphenous vein harvested from an uninjured leg. A reverse saphenous vein graft is a saphenous vein with blood flow reversed and valves lysed. 
  • Great saphaenous vein is preferred because elastic properties, adequate size match and  non —thrombogenic.
 

Reference:Rutherfords Vascular Surgery And Endovascular Therapy 9 Edition Page no 1446

questions.text:
Organize the following in increasing stability order.
(i) Ilizarov circle fixator
(ii) Biplanar frame at right angle
(iii) Uniplanar with one rod
(iv) Uniplanar with two rods
questions.solution:
Order of Stability—

Ilizarov Circle Fixator > Biplanar Frame at Right Angle > Uniplanar with 2 rods > Uniplanar with 1 rod.

  • Uniplanar with one rod - This is the least stable of all the options as it is constructed in only one plane with a single rod. 
  • Uniplanar with two rods - This is more stable than the previous option as it has two rods in the same plane.
  •  Biplanar frame at right angle - This is more stable than the uniplanar options as it is constructed in two planes at right angles to each other.
  • lizarov circle fixator - This is the most stable option as it is constructed in multiple planes with multiple rings and wires, providing excellent stability and control over the bone fragments.
 

Reference-:Textbook of Orthopedics by John Ebnezar  5th Edition Page nos 76, 77                     
                     Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari 5th edition Page no 374

questions.text:
Following an RTA, a patient was brought to the casualty. After being examined, it was discovered that he had a femur shaft fracture that needed to be stabilised with tibial traction. Which of the following are essential elements for skeletal traction?
(i) Thomas splint
(ii) Bohler stirrup
(iii) Steinmann pin
(iv) K wire
(v) Bohler frame
(vi) Denham’s pin
questions.solution:
Skeletal traction is a treatment method to treat broken bones.  It is a system where combination of pulleys, pins and weights are used to promote the healing of fractured bones. They are usually done in the lower body.

Equipments required for tibial Skeletal Traction—

Steinmann Pin , Bohler Stirrup, Bohler -Brawn Splint and weights to provide traction.


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 141

questions.text: After an RTA, a patient complained of a hip injury. Abduction of the lower limbs combined with external rotation of the hip is most likely related to:
questions.solution:
• Most likely association is anterior dislocation of hip.
  • In case of anterior dislocation of hip the attitude seen is flexion, abduction and external rotation.
  • Differentiation of PDH and ADH on X ray-  
  1. ADH- Larger head of femur
  2. PDH- Smaller head in comparison to normal side
  • Posterior dislocation of hip- Flexion, adduction and Internal rotation.
  • There is marked shortening of limb in PDH.
  • Vascular sign of Narath is Positive
  • 50% of PDH is associated with posterior chip fracture of acetabulum.
Memorizing Trick- 
Anterior Dislocation- FABER- Flexion ABduction External Rotation 
Posterior Dislocation- FADIR- Flexion ADduction Internal Rotation 


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 131

questions.text:
Match the following with the correct option.

Name of fracture Fracture site
i. Boxer’s fracture a. 2nd metatarsal
ii. Bennett’s fracture b. 5th metacarpal
iii. March fracture c. 5th metatarsal
iv. Jone’s fracture d. 1st metacarpal
 

1. i-b, ii - d, iii - a, iv - c
2. i-b, ii - d, iii - c, iv - a
3. i-d, ii - b, iii - c, iv - a
4. i-c, ii - b, iii - a, iv - d
questions.solution:
• Boxers fracture- 5th metacarpal
  • Bennets fracture- 1st metacarpal
  • March fracture- 2 nd metatarsal
  • Jones fracture- 5th metatarsal

Boxer's fracture is a fracture of the neck of the fifth metacarpal bone.
Bennett's fracture is a fracture of the base of the 1st metacarpal bone, which is seen in individuals who fall on an outstretched hand with the thumb in abduction.
March fracture is a stress fracture of the metatarsal bones most commonly the 2nd metatarsal.
Jones fracture is a fracture of the base of the 5th metatarsal bone of the foot, which is commonly seen in individuals who participate in sports that involve running and jumping


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 367 Annexure 2

questions.text: What is the most delayed indication of compartment syndrome?
questions.solution:
1.  An externally applied compressive force or an expanding internal force are the two most frequent causes (such as an arterial bleed, overexertion, or a fracture) for compartment syndrome.  
    Features: 
  • Severe pain (a "bursting" sensation) is the earliest of the "classic" symptoms followed by Pallor and paraesthesia. 
  • Pulselessness 
  • Paralysis is last to appear.

choices.text: Compartment syndrome can be seen in open fractures

questions.text: Which of the following statements about open fracture is false?
questions.solution:
• Tibia bone is commonly involved in open fractures due to its location and vulnerability to injury.
  • Immediate debridement, which involves the removal of any foreign material or contaminated tissue from the wound, is crucial in reducing the risk of infection in open fractures.
  • Compartment syndrome is a potential complication of open fractures where pressure builds up within the muscles and tissues surrounding the fracture, leading to decreased blood flow and potential nerve damage.It could be related to the injury or related with the treatment ie Cast Application
  • Open fractures are often associated with additional injuries- Most serious ones are Neurovascular injuries, hence it is the wrong statement.

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 7,21,22,155

questions.text: A 2 years old child with history of fall one year back with skull bone fracture (parietal line fracture) now presented with painful and growing parietal swelling. What is the most probable cause of the swelling?
questions.solution:
A two-year-old child who experienced a skull fracture one year ago is now presenting with a painful and expanding swelling over the parietal region. The most likely diagnosis is leptomeningeal cyst, which is also known as a "growing fracture".

This condition is common in children under four and normally involves a fracture in the temporal area that does not heal but increases in size due to herniation of arachnoid into the fracture line through a tear in the dura that was created at the time of the initial trauma.

Surgery is needed to remove the cyst and or the arachnoid tear. 


Other options
  • A growing scalp hematoma may occur after trauma, but it typically resolves within a few weeks.
  • A subdural hygroma is a collection of cerebrospinal fluid within the subdural space, which may occur after trauma or surgery, but it typically presents as a non-painful, fluctuant swelling.
  • Chronic abscess is also less likely in this case, as it typically presents with fever, localized warmth, and tenderness, which are not mentioned in the scenario


Reference-: Online resource https://www.ajnr.org/ajnr-case-collections-diagnosis/growing-skull-fracture

questions.text: An individual who has sustained a supracondylar humerus fracture is unable to flex their thumb's interphalangeal joint. Which nerve is likely to be hurt?
questions.solution:

  • This nerve supplies the flexor pollicis longus, which produces flexion of the interphalangeal joint of the thumb.

questions.text: Which kind of Gustilo and Anderson compound fracture has substantial soft tissue damage and periosteal stripping?
questions.solution:
Gustilo-Anderson classification

  • grade 1: clean wound <1 cm in length
  • grade 2: wound 1-10 cm in length without extensive soft-tissue damage, flaps or avulsions
  • grade 3: extensive soft-tissue laceration (>10 cm) or tissue loss/damage or an open segmental fracture
    • open fractures caused by
    • farm injuries
    • injuries requiring vascular intervention
    • fractures that have been open for 8 hours prior to treatment

Grade 3 injuries can be further subdivided by the degree of periosteal and vascular injury and soft tissue loss:

  • grade 3a: adequate periosteal coverage of the fracture bone despite the extensive soft-tissue laceration or damage
  • grade 3b
    • extensive soft-tissue loss, periosteal stripping and bone damage
    • usually associated with massive contamination
    • will often need further soft-tissue coverage procedure (e.g. free or rotational flap)
  • grade 3c: associated with an arterial injury requiring repair, irrespective of degree of soft-tissue injury 

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 21

questions.text: Which of the following skull views shows the Mcgrigor-Campbell lines?
questions.solution:
•  McGrigor-Campbell lines are used in maxillofacial surgery to assess the degree of displacement of the fracture fragments.
  • These lines are drawn along the anterior and posterior walls of the maxillary sinus and the floor of the orbit.
  • The intersection of these lines is used as a reference point to determine the degree of displacement of the fracture fragments.
  • Of the four skull views listed, the Occipitomental view is the only one that shows the McGrigor-Campbell lines

questions.solution:

  • These are incomplete fractures that occur in bones due to repeated stress or strain rather than a single traumatic event.
  • Milkman's fracture specifically refers to a pseudo-fracture that occurs in the Pubic ramus.

choices.text: Tears at the junction of anterior horn of medial meniscus & tibial collateral ligament

questions.text: Which of the following meniscal tears will require a meniscectomy rather than a repair?
questions.solution:
• When a meniscal tear occurs in the outer zone of the meniscus, it is usually close to the blood supply and has a better chance of healing naturally. These tears can often be treated with conservative management, such as rest, ice, and physical therapy, or with a meniscal repair surgery if the tear is large or unstable. In meniscus outer 1/3rd is vascular and inner 2/3rd is avascular. 
  • When a meniscal tear occurs in the middle zone of the meniscus, it is less likely to heal on its own due to poor blood supply. However, a meniscal repair surgery may still be attempted if the tear is in a repairable location and the tissue quality is good.
  • When a meniscal tear occurs in the inner zone of the meniscus, it is far away from the blood supply and has a very low chance of healing naturally. In such cases, a meniscectomy, which involves removing the damaged portion of the meniscus, is usually the preferred treatment option



Reference-:https://www.physio-pedia.com/Meniscal_Lesions

questions.text: Which Salter-Harris type describes a fracture including the epiphysis, Diaphysis, and Metaphysis?
questions.solution:
• Type IV Salter-Harris fracture involves the epiphysis, physis, and metaphysis.
  • In this type of fracture, there is a fracture through the growth plate, epiphysis, and metaphysis, which can result in growth disturbances and deformities.

questions.text: Which of the following does not include The Unhappy Triad of O'Donoghue?
questions.solution:
• O'Donoghue unhappy triad or terrible triad often occurs in contact and non-contact sports, such as basketball, football, or rugby, when there is a lateral force applied to the knee while the foot is fixated on the ground.
  • This produces an abduction-external rotation mechanism of injury ("pivot shift" in non-contact sports).
  • It comprises three types of soft tissue injury that frequently tend to occur simultaneously in knee injuries. O'Donoghue described the injuries as:
  1. Anterior cruciate ligament tear
  2. Medial collateral ligament injury
  3. Medial meniscal tear 

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 149

questions.text: A young male had a road traffic accident and presented to the Emergency with multiple injuries. After 2 days, he developed tachypnea, petechial rash and became drowsy. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of fat embolism.

questions.text: Which of the following is a Salter Harris type 1 fracture
questions.solution:

  • B-fracture through a portion of the physis that extends through the metaphysis;

questions.text: A 25-year-old male who sustained a shoulder injury presented with swelling around the shoulder joint. An X-ray of the shoulder joint is shown below. Which is/are the ligament(s) likely to have been injured?
questions.solution:
• The image indicates that the clavicle has been displaced upwards, creating a gap between the clavicle and the acromion. This suggests damage to both the acromioclavicular and coracoclavicular ligaments.
 
  • The acromioclavicular joint, a synovial plane joint, is formed between the acromial end of the clavicle and the medial margin of the acromion. It is supported by two key ligaments: the acromioclavicular (intrinsic) ligament and the coracoclavicular (extrinsic) ligament. The acromioclavicular ligament has two components: the superior part runs from the upper side of the clavicle‘s lateral end to the adjacent acromion, while the inferior part extends from the lower surface of the clavicle‘s lateral end to the adjoining acromion. This ligament also serves as the attachment site for the intra-articular disc.
 
  • The coracoclavicular ligament, which links the clavicle to the coracoid process of the scapula, is separate from the acromioclavicular joint but crucial for maintaining the alignment between the acromion and the clavicle. This ligament supports the scapula‘s suspension and comprises two parts: the trapezoid and the conoid ligaments.
 
  • Injuries typically occur due to direct trauma to the lateral shoulder or acromion when the arm is adducted, or from falls onto an outstretched hand or elbow.
 
  • To diagnose acromioclavicular joint injuries, standard X-rays are generally sufficient. They can be used to identify injuries by comparing the coracoclavicular interspace distance with that of the unaffected side, and to assess other potential sources of shoulder pain resulting from trauma.



Reference: Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st edition, Page no 787, 803.

questions.text: A patient came to the emergency department with a history of road traffic accident and a shaft of femur fracture. The patient was stabilized. After 12 hours, he developed sudden onset breathlessness, confusion, and petechial skin rashes over the chest and axilla. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Fat embolism is likely the diagnosis in the given clinical scenario. It occurs when fat globules from the bone marrow enter the bloodstream, typically following a fracture of long bones. The clinical features of fat embolism usually present within 72 hours and include tachycardia, fever, breathlessness, petechiae, confusion, and restlessness. The diagnosis of fat embolism syndrome is guided by Gurd‘s criteria. Although there is no definitive test for fat embolism, diagnostic approaches include urine analysis to detect fat globules and monitoring blood pO2 levels. Management is primarily supportive, with oxygen therapy being a key component.

 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2091,2093,2094,2095,2121,2122 .

questions.text: A patient sustained a fracture as depicted in the image, following a fall from height. What is this fracture known as?
questions.solution:
Open book fracture is the type of fracture depicted in the picture.

Pubic diastasis and/or a fracture of the pubic rami with a posterior pelvic dislocation of the sacroiliac joint are linked to open book fractures.

Alternatives

The sacroiliac joint (SI joint) or ilium close to the SI joint on the same side posteriorly and the pubic rami anteriorly are both affected by Malgaigne's fracture (picture below).

A bucket handle fracture is a vertically oriented fracture that disrupts the contralateral sacroiliac joint and occurs through the ipsilateral superior and inferior pubic rami.

The term "Chauffeur's fracture" describes a fracture of the forearm's radial styloid process.

Reference: Essential Orthopaedics 4th edition page no 3

questions.text: A young patient is diagnosed with an irreparable rotator cuff tear. What will be the preferred treatment?
questions.solution:
• Treatment of choice for irreparable tear of the rotator cuff in a young patient is tendon transfer.
  • Hemiarthroplasty can provide good long-term results in rotator cuff-deficient patients with glenohumeral arthritis.
  • Total shoulder replacement  and reverse shoulder replacement  are typically reserved for cases where there is severe arthritis or other joint damage in addition to the rotator cuff tear.
  • Acromioplasty  is a surgical procedure to remove a small portion of the acromion bone in the shoulder to relieve pressure on the rotator cuff tendons, but it is not typically used for irreparable rotator cuff tears.



Reference-:https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK547664/

  • Recurrent shoulder dislocation is the most common complication of shoulder dislocation.

questions.text:
Analgesic is administered to an adult wearing a POP cast for a forearm fracture.
What is the earliest way for a nurse to recognise the development of compartment syndrome?
questions.solution:
Earliest way to detect development of compartment syndrome by the nurse is decreased response to analgesics.
  • When a patient experiences compartment syndrome, the affected area may become increasingly painful, and the pain may not respond to analgesics as expected.
  • This is because the pressure within the muscle compartment can compress nerves and blood vessels, leading to reduced blood flow and tissue damage.
  • Therefore, a decreased response to analgesic is a sign that the patient may be developing compartment syndrome and requires immediate medical attention.
  • Management- Fasciotomy 

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 47

questions.text: A person can abduct his arm, rotate it internally, and lay the back of his hand on the lumbosacral joint, but he cannot lift it from behind. What exactly is aetiology?
questions.solution:
• Subscapularis tendon tear occurs when there is  sudden or awkward movement of the arm.
  • Due to the tear, the person is able to abduct the arm and move it away from the body and internally rotate it, due to the downward pull of gravity. However, they are not able to lift it up from the back, Lift off Test.
  • This is because the subscapularis muscle aids in the lifting and adduction of the arm, and its damaged tendon can no longer provide that function.

Lift off test 
 

Reference-:Apley & Solomon's System of Orthopaedics and Trauma 10th Edition Page no 360

questions.text: Which muscles are impacted by De Quervain tenosynovitis
questions.solution:
• De Quervain tenosynovitis, also known as washerwoman's sprain/strain, is a painful stenosing tenosynovitis involving the first extensor (dorsal) tendon compartment of the wrist (typically at the radial styloid).
  • This compartment contains the abductor pollicis longus (APL) and extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) tendons.

questions.text: Lift off test is conducted to test the function of:
questions.solution:

questions.text: Pain at the base of the thumb is evident in the patient (De Quervain tenosynovitis). What are the image's marks?
questions.solution:
• De Quervain tenosynovitis is an inflammation of the tendon sheaths located on the radial side of the wrist. These sheaths surround two muscles of the thumb: the abductor pollicis longs and extensor pollicis brevis.
  • When the outer part of the wrist, at the base of the thumb, is tender to the touch and causes pain with repetitive movements, it is generally a sign of De Quervain tenosynovitis.
  • Treatment may include anti-inflammatory medications, corticosteroid injections, rest, splinting or physical therapy.
  • In severe cases, surgery may be recommended.

questions.text: What is the following sign known as and what is the cause?
questions.solution:
• Popeye deformity is a condition that occurs when a tendon in the biceps muscle of the arm tears.
  • The biceps muscle then bunches up and forms a large, painful ball-like bulge above the elbow in the upper arm, giving it the appearance of Popeye's cartoon muscular arms.
  • This condition can be very painful and can limit the arm's normal range of motion.
  • Treatment typically involves rest, physical therapy, medications, and in some cases surgery.

Inverted Champagne bottle appearance is seen in lipodermatosclerosis 
Olive sign is seen in infants with pyloric stenosis

questions.text: The most accurate test to diagnose carpal tunnel syndrome is:
questions.solution:
• Most specific test for carpel tunnel syndrome is Durkan test.
  • Durkan test, which involves applying direct pressure to the carpal tunnel for 30 seconds. This test is considered to be more sensitive and specific than other commonly used tests
  • Phalen test involves holding the wrist in a flexed position for 60 seconds, while the Tourniquet test involves inflating a blood pressure cuff around the upper arm and leaving it in place for several minutes to increase pressure in the carpal tunnel.
  • The Cozen test is a test for lateral epicondylitis (tennis elbow) and is not used for diagnosing carpal tunnel syndrome.


   


Reference- Campbell’s operative orthopaedics 14 Edition Page no 3858

questions.text: Uses for a counterforce brace include:
questions.solution:
Counter force brace is used in tennis elbow.
  • Counterforce braces help keep pressure off of the inflamed muscles by spreading tension to different parts of arm.
  • Instead of continually stressing the same forearm muscles and tendons when making certain movements, wearing a counterforce brace allows them to rest by re-distributing this pressure. Below is image of counterforce brace

questions.text: A 65-year-old alcoholic suffering from diabetes has a flexion deformity of the right little finger over the metacarpophalangeal joint of around 15 degrees. What is the ideal management?

Avascular necrosis: The blood supply of the scaphoid is precarious. In fractures through the waist, there is high probability of the proximal fragment becoming avascular. The patient complains of pain and weakness of the wrist. On the X-ray one finds non-union of the fracture with sclerosis and crushing of the proximal pole of the scaphoid. Treatment: It is a difficult problem to treat. If the patient is symptomatic, the avascular segment of the bone is excised. In some cases, the wrist develops osteoarthritis, and is treated accordingly.

Reference: Essential Orthopedics, J. Maheshwari, 7th Edition, Page. No- 115.

questions.text: Three point bony relationship of elbow will be preserved in?

Three point bony relationship is maintained in Supra condylar fracture humerus.
The three landmarks are Medial and Lateral epicondyle and olecranon.
Most common cause is due to fall in outstretched arms seen in children 5-7 years

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presented to the OPD with the findings. He had suffered a fall on an outstretched hand one year back. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of a fall on an outstretched hand, along with the presence of a gunstock deformity as seen in the image, suggests malunion of a supracondylar fracture of the humerus.

Cubitus varus, or gunstock deformity, is a known complication of supracondylar humerus fracture healing with malunion.




Supracondylar Fracture of Humerus
  • Most common type - Posterior displacement of the distal fragment (also known as an extension-type fracture).
  • The distal fracture fragment is displaced posteriorly and unites with an excessive backward tilt, causing and hyperextension of the elbow - resulting in Gunstock deformity
  • Supracondylar fracture of humerus are most common type of fracture in children <7 years caused due to a fall on an outstretched arm.(FOOSH)

choices.text: Fracture of the coronoid process of ulna

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in the terrible triad of the elbow?
questions.solution:
• The terrible triad of the elbow refers to a combination of injuries that makes the elbow highly unstable:

    1. Radial head fracture

    2. Coronoid process fracture of the ulna

    3. Posterior elbow dislocation

  • Olecranon fracture is not part of this triad. It represents a separate pattern of injury usually from direct trauma or fall on the elbow.

  • Clinical relevance: This triad is associated with high risk of instability, stiffness, and post-traumatic arthritis, requiring careful surgical management.

questions.text: A patient presents with elbow deformity and forearm shortening after a fall. An X-ray was done and given below. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The clinical history and X-ray findings indicate an elbow dislocation, specifically a posterior dislocation of the elbow joint.



This type of dislocation is the most prevalent in the pediatric population and ranks as the second most common dislocation after the shoulder in adults. Posterior dislocations are the most frequent, often resulting from a fall on an outstretched hand with the elbow slightly flexed. Other types of dislocations include postero-medial, posterolateral, and divergent dislocations.

An anterior dislocation typically occurs when the elbow is flexed and subjected to a direct blow on its posterior aspect.

questions.text: Diagnose the following x-ray
questions.solution:
The given x-ray shows fracture of scaphoid bone.
  • Scaphoid fractures account for 70-80% of all carpal bone fractures.
  • Although they occur essentially at any age, adolescents and young adults are most commonly affected.
  • Patients will typically present with pain around the dorsal wrist and/or the anatomical snuffbox after a fall on an outstretched hand
Reference: Essential Orthopedics, J. Maheshwari, 7th Edition, Page No 115.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient presents with complaints of pain and swelling in the left wrist following a fall on an outstretched hand. On examination, dinner fork deformity can be noticed. What is the most likely displacement seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario described is indicative of a Colles' fracture, characterized by proximal and dorsal displacement of the radius.

Colles' fracture frequently occurs in postmenopausal women following a fall onto an outstretched hand.

Clinical presentation: Patients typically present with pain, swelling, and deformity of the wrist, along with tenderness. The condition is associated with a "dinner fork deformity," which features a prominence at the back of the wrist and a depression at the front, resulting from the dorsal angulation of the distal fracture fragment. The radial styloid process may be positioned at the same level or slightly higher than the ulnar styloid process.



Types of displacement seen in a Colles' fracture may include:

Dorsal tilt
Dorsal shift
Lateral tilt (radial tilt)
Lateral shift (radial shift)
Supination
Impaction of the fragment
Proximal shift
Diagnosis:

Diagnosis is confirmed through X-ray imaging, which typically reveals a transverse fracture of the radius at the cortico-cancellous junction, with dorsal tilt being the most common finding.
Management:

For undisplaced fractures, immobilization in a below-elbow plaster cast is recommended for six weeks.
Displaced fractures require manipulative reduction followed by immobilization in a Colles' cast positioned in palmar flexion, pronation, and ulnar deviation.
Comminuted fractures may be treated by transfixing the fragments percutaneously with two K-wires.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presents with painful swelling in the middle finger around the proximal phalanx. An X-ray was done and it is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and X-ray findings suggest a diagnosis of enchondroma.



Enchondromas are benign tumors made up of a lobulated mass of cartilage enclosed by fibrous tissue. They are most commonly found in individuals aged 20 to 30 years and typically occur in the small bones of the hands and feet, as well as in the femur and humerus.

Patients usually present with long-standing swelling in one or more phalanges or metacarpals, often with minimal pain. Diagnosis is primarily made through X-ray, which can reveal expanding lytic lesions; in some cases, a biopsy may be necessary if the diagnosis remains uncertain. Enchondromas located in long bones have the potential for malignant transformation into chondrosarcoma.

Treatment involves curettage (surgical removal) and is recommended if the patient experiences pain or suffers a pathological fracture.

questions.text: A young male following a fall on an outstretched hand had the following X-ray. Identify the fracture
questions.solution: The given X-ray shows scaphoid bone fracture. A scaphoid fracture is the most common carpal fracture. Direct axial compression or hyperextension of the wrist, such as with a fall onto an outstretched hand, results in a scaphoid fracture. Ref- Apley's system of orthopaedics 10th edition Page 805-809

questions.text: A 30 year old male presented with deformity of the hand as shown in the image. He gives history of RTA and fracture of the same limb in the past. Which of the following nerves is involved in the given condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical image shows clawing of medial two fingers which is seen in ulnar neuropathy.
The ulnar nerve supplies the medial two lumbricals, adductor pollicis, interossei, and hypothenar muscles in the hand. The lumbricals are primarily responsible for the extension at the interphalangeal joints.
Therefore, in ulnar nerve palsy, there is clawing of the medial two fingers due to unopposed action of the long flexors.
Essential Orthopaedics by Maheswari, 5th edition • page 65-68

questions.text: Patient comes to following history of fall with his thumb extended and now presents with painful and swollen thumb. Below is his X ray. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Bennett fracture is a fracture-dislocation at the base of the first metacarpal bone , involving the carpometacarpal (CMC) joint. It is typically caused by a direct impact or force on a flexed thumb, often seen in sports or falls. It is a Intra-articular fracture.
Results in displacement of the metacarpal due to the pull of the abductor pollicis longus tendon. Ref Essential orthopaedics by Maheswari 5th edition Page 122

questions.text: A patient presents with swelling and tenderness in the anatomical snuffbox after sustaining a fall onto an outstretched hand. The following cast was applied to the patient. What fracture did the patient suffer from?
questions.solution:
The scaphoid cast, sometimes called the glassholding cast, is the cast that is used on a patient when they are holding a glass. The treatment for scaphoid fractures is with it.

 

The patient has tenderness in the anatomical snuffbox after a fall onto an outstretched hand (FOOSH).
Key points:

  • Anatomical snuffbox tenderness is classic for scaphoid fracture.

  • Mechanism of injury: FOOSH with the wrist in extension and radial deviation.

  • Complications if missed: Non-union, avascular necrosis due to retrograde blood supply of the scaphoid.

  • Casting: Typically, a thumb spica cast is applied to immobilize the scaphoid.

Other options:

  • Colles’ fracture: Distal radius fracture with dorsal angulation; swelling is more generalized, not limited to snuffbox.

  • Smith’s fracture: Distal radius fracture with volar angulation.

  • Galeazzi fracture: Distal radius fracture with dislocation of distal radioulnar joint.


Reference:Rockwood and Greens fractures in Adults 8th edition page no 169,999,1005

questions.text: A six-year-old child presented with the given deformity. Identify the deformity.
questions.solution:
The child presents with a deformity at the elbow characterized by increased carrying angle, meaning the forearm deviates away from the body when the arm is extended.

  • Cubitus valgus: Increased carrying angle → forearm angled outward.

  • Cubitus varus (Gun stock deformity): Decreased carrying angle → forearm angled inward.

  • Coxa vara / Coxa valga: Hip deformities, not relevant here.

Since the forearm is deviated outward, the diagnosis is: Cubitus valgus



Reference:Campbells operative orthopaedics page no 1439

questions.text: While examining a patient with a right forearm fracture, you ask him to make a fist. The following finding is noted during this procedure. What is the sign called as ?
questions.solution:
The Pointing Index Sign is classically associated with injury to the anterior interosseous nerve (AIN), a motor branch of the median nerve. This finding is particularly relevant in the setting of supracondylar fractures of the humerus, especially in children.

Key Features

  • Mechanism:
    Injury to the AIN impairs function of:

    • Flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) to the index finger

    • Flexor pollicis longus (FPL)

    As a result, when the patient attempts to make a fist:

    • The index finger remains extended, as it cannot flex at the distal interphalangeal joint.

    • The other fingers flex normally.

    This causes the index finger to “point” while others form a fist.

  • Clinical Relevance:
    Most commonly seen in:

    • Supracondylar fractures of the humerus

    • Penetrating trauma or compression neuropathies of the median nerve

      Associated Clinical Signs

Sign Nerve Involved Clinical Feature
Froment's Sign Ulnar nerve Flexion of thumb IP joint when gripping paper due to adductor pollicis weakness
Benediction Sign Median nerve Inability to flex index and middle fingers when making a fist
Ochsner's Clasping Test Median nerve Pointing index observed during clasping of hands, indicating FDP weakness
Waiter's Tip Deformity Upper trunk (C5–C6) Arm adducted, internally rotated, forearm extended and pronated
 

The Pointing Index Sign serves as a valuable clinical marker of anterior interosseous nerve dysfunction, typically due to median nerve injury in the forearm or around the elbow. Prompt recognition, especially in post-traumatic scenarios like supracondylar fractures, is essential for early diagnosis and appropriate management of nerve injuries.


Reference:Apley and Solomon's system of Orthopaedics and Trauma 10th edition page no
297

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with supraspinatus tendinitis. What degree of movement of the shoulder would be painful for this patient?
questions.solution:
Shoulder impingement syndrome, also known as supraspinatus syndrome or painful arc syndrome, is a condition characterized by irritation and inflammation of the rotator cuff tendons, primarily the supraspinatus tendon, as they pass through the subacromial space. This condition leads to shoulder pain, particularly during overhead activities, along with weakness and restricted range of motion.

The underlying mechanism involves supraspinatus tendinitis, typically caused by repetitive microtrauma as the tendon impinges against the coraco-acromial arch during arm elevation, especially between 60 and 120 degrees—a range known as the painful arc.

Clinically, shoulder impingement can be categorized into stages:

  • In subacute tendinitis, patients experience anterior shoulder pain following strenuous or repetitive overhead activity. Management includes rest, activity modification, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), and structured physiotherapy.

  • Chronic tendinitis presents with recurring pain episodes, frequently worsening at night. Persistent inflammation may lead to tendon degeneration. Management remains conservative initially but may necessitate escalation if symptoms persist.

  • In rotator cuff disruption, there is progressive pain and marked weakness of shoulder abduction or rotation. This stage may result in partial or full-thickness tears. Surgical interventions such as acromioplasty (to decompress the subacromial space) and rotator cuff repair may be indicated.

Diagnosis is primarily clinical, supported by specific examination maneuvers. The Neer impingement test and Hawkins-Kennedy test are commonly used to reproduce impingement pain. Imaging studies such as MRI or musculoskeletal ultrasound help assess tendon integrity and identify fluid, edema, or tears in the rotator cuff complex.


Reference:Apleys system of Orthopaedics and Fractures 10th edition page no 343

questions.text: What area of the body's X-ray shows the Shenton line?
questions.solution:

questions.text: An individual in his 40s describes acutely developing pain and swelling in his left great toe. On X-ray, a phalanx-based lytic lesion with overhanging bony borders and sclerotic margins is visible. The correct diagnosis would be:
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis is gout. 
  • Gout is a crystal arthropathy due to deposition of monosodium urate crystals in and around the joints.
  • Acute gouty arthritis presents with a monoarticular red, inflamed, swollen joint, typically in the lower limb and classically affecting the first metatarsophalangeal joint. 
  • The drug of choice for an acute attack of gout is NSAIDs. 
  • Allopurinol is not given in acute gout. It is rather drug of choice for chronic gout.

questions.text: What is the earliest indication of compartment syndrome of the leg?
questions.solution:
• Pain on passive stretching are early indicators whereas paraesthesia, paralysis and pulselessness occur late.
  • It is important to thoroughly and regularly assess skin sensations. Muscles which are ischemic are very sensitive to stretching. Stretching should be used to test the muscles, which may be tender, if the limb is excessively painful, swollen, or tense.
  • There is increased pain in the calf or forearm when the toes or fingers are passively hyperextended.
  • Pulses may still be felt and the skin may not be pale in compartment syndrome because the ischemia occurs at the capillary level.
  • Definitive management is fasciotomy. 

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 47

questions.text: A patient complained of lower limb weakness. The examiner lays one hand beneath the patient's heel and instructs the patient to elevate his other leg against downward resistance. What is the name of this examination?

questions.text:
A 40-year-old bodybuilder on steroids and creatinine complained of bilateral hip pain and inability to squat.
There is marrow edoema, a subchondral cyst, flattening of the weight-bearing portions of the femoral head on MRI, and a crescent sign on X-ray.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above history is highly suggestive of avascular necrosis (Osteonecrosis) of femur.

Clinical characteristics:
  • Post-traumatic osteonecrosis appears shortly after a hip injury, though symptoms and signs may take months to manifest.
  • Non traumatic osteonecrosis is more sneaky. Children are impacted by illnesses such Gaucher's disease, sickle cell disease, and Perthes disease.
  • Hip pain is the primary complaint, which becomes worse over the course of two to three years and eventually becomes extremely severe.
  • Below is image of Crescent sign in AVN

questions.text: Which of the following statements concerning the posterior cruciate ligament is false?
questions.solution:
• When the knee is under varus (stress directed towards the midline), the lateral collateral ligament (LCL), not the posterior cruciate ligament (PCL), prevents internal rotation of the tibia on the femur.
  • The PCL stops the femur from pressing anteriorly against the tibia.
  • The PCL avoids the tibia from being dragged posteriorly when the knee joint is flexed.


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 149, 145

questions.text: What is the purpose of Gallows traction?
questions.solution:
• Gallow’s traction is an orthopaedic traction used in infants and children less than 2 years of age for treatment of a fracture shaft of the femur. This traction is used to keep the leg straight, to maintain alignment of the leg bones, and to reduce muscle spasms.
  • Russet's traction or Thomas splint is an orthopaedic traction that is used to treat a fracture shaft of the femur in older children. It is similar to Gallow’s traction, but instead of the leg being suspended in a traction splint, it is secured by a heavy plaster cast. This cast also serves to provide additional support and maintain alignment. This traction also helps to reduce muscle spasms, making the leg more comfortable and easier to manage.


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 27

questions.text:
A senior citizen who had earlier fallen in the bathroom was immobile. Later, she had legs that were rotated externally. Scarpa's triangle and limb were both sensitive.
Pain prevented him from moving around. No hip fracture could be revealed on the X-ray. What comes after this in the procedure?
questions.solution:
• Scarpa's triangle is an anatomical region located around the hip joint, which is vulnerable to fractures due to its delicate bone and tissue structure.
  • An externally rotated leg in this area is indicative of a fracture of the neck of the femur.
  • It is usually caused by a direct impact to the hip and can be accompanied by severe tenderness when touched. Due to the complexity of the hip joint, a fracture of the neck of the femur is often difficult to detect on a standard X-ray. Therefore, an MRI or a bone scan may be needed to confirm the presence of the fracture.

 Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 140

questions.text: While playing hockey, a 24-year-old college student hurt his right knee. After 3 months, this patient presents with knee joint instability in full extension without instability at 90 degrees of flexion. What is the most usually damaged structure?

questions.text: Which of the following statements about 'Menisci' is inaccurate
questions.solution:
The inaccurate statement is: 1. Medial meniscus is more mobile than lateral

Explanation:
The lateral meniscus is more mobile than the medial meniscus due to its looser attachment to the tibia and absence of a strong connection to the joint capsule and medial collateral ligament (MCL).
The medial meniscus is more firmly attached to the tibia and MCL, making it less mobile and more prone to injury.

Other options

  1. Lateral meniscus covers more tibial articular surface than medial – The lateral meniscus is larger, more circular, and covers a greater portion of the tibial plateau.

  2. Medial meniscus is more commonly injured than lateral – Due to its firm attachment to the MCL and tibial plateau, the medial meniscus is less mobile and more susceptible to injury, especially in twisting injuries.

  3. Menisci are predominantly made up of type I collagen – Menisci are primarily composed of Type I collagen, which provides tensile strength, making this statement accurate.



Reference- Textbook of Orthopedics by John Ebnezar fourth edition Page no 254

questions.text: Painful swelling of the great toe, and periarticular erosions were seen in a 54-year-old male. Likely Diagnosis?

Option A- RA is more frequently encountered in middle age women. It involves the small joints of hands and is characterized by early morning stiffness. 

Option B- SLE is also more commonly seen in middle aged women characterized by malar rash, photosensitivity and erosive arthritis involving small joints. 

Option D- Pseudogout is a type of arthritis that results from deposition of calcium pyrophosphate crystals in large joints of the body.

questions.text: What is the probable Dx in case where a 28 year old man who has recently finished a half marathon,complains of pain along the anterior and medial aspect of the tibia which increases on jogging and walking for a long time and his X-ray was found to be (N).

  • Shin splints may be a mild form of anterior compartment syndrome.
  • Exercise-induced discomfort at the distal two-thirds of the medial tibial border, pain triggered during or after physical activity, and a normal X-ray are all characteristics that point to the diagnosis.

questions.text: A patient having a cast on for a tibial fracture arrived to the emergency room complaining of pain in the affected limb. His cast was removed, and an examination revealed pain with passive flexion of the affected limb, loss of sensation in the first web space, and the presence of dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses. What is the ideal course of action for moving forward?
questions.solution:
• The diagnosis most likely is evolving compartment syndrome secondary to tibial fracture. 
  • Pulse is not a reliable indicator as it is the last to disappear and therefore, doppler parameters will remain normal till the very end. Therefore, we rule out option C. 
  • Note- Most common cause of compartment syndrome is Diaphyseal fracture of tibia. 
  • Most common cause of compartment syndrome in children is supracondylar fracture of humerus.

questions.text:
Which of the following is the correct sequence for performing the Thomas test?
(i) Squaring of pelvis
(ii) Flexion of hip
(iii) Look for exaggerated lumbar lordosis
(iv) Measure actual flexion deformity
(v) Ensure that ischial tuberosity touches the ground
(vi) Overcorrection of the normal side.
questions.solution:
The correct sequence is option C- 32654
Thomas test is used for diagnosis of flexion deformity of hip. 

Steps-

1. Patient is asked to lay supine to check for exaggerated lumbar lordosis. 

2. Ask the patient to flex the hip gradually. 

3. If flexion of hip is done beyond normal limit, it will result in overcorrection of the normal side in the form of lifting up of pelvis.  This can be avoided by ensuring both the ischial tuberosities touch the ground. 

4. When the ischial tuberosities will touch the ground, the affected hip will come to lie in its deformed diseased position of flexion deformity. 

5. Measure the angle between the affected thigh and ground to obtain actual degree of flexion of deformity. 



Reference- Textbook of Orthopedics by John Ebnezar fourth edition Page no 432

questions.text: Following a meniscal injury, the following repairs yield the greatest results:
questions.solution:
Best results after meniscal injury is seen in repair of red zone.

The results are best in case of repair of red zone (peripheral part) because it is more vascular as compared to the white zone (central part ).

questions.text: Which muscle atrophy happens more frequently in people with osteoarthritis of the knee joint?
questions.solution:
• In patients with osteoarthritis of knee joint, atrophy occurs most commonly in Quadriceps muscle.
  • Quadriceps femoris (vastus medialis component) is the first (earliest), most commonly and most involved muscle in osteoarthritis. It may under go wasting or atrophy.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman arrived with contracture in her hip flexors. What test should be performed in this situation?
questions.solution:
• Thomas' test.- During the test the hips are bent to its maximum point at the same time, removing the lumbar lordosis; the sound hip is held motionless (keeping the pelvis stable) while the other leg is lowered intimately.
  • If the knee of the affected limb cannot reach the seat it is indicative of the existence of a flexion deformity.
  • Allis Test- Used to assess for hip dislocation, developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH), and leg length discrepancies.



 
  • Thomas test

questions.text: A moving vehicle hits a pedestrian on his lateral aspect of the knee and causes a fracture. The fracture line is passing through the intercondylar eminence. Which of the following structures will most likely by injured?
questions.solution:
Anterior cruciate ligament is the structure that is most likely to be injured.

The fracture results from forced abduction from the lateral side of the knee. The intercondylar prominence is where the fracture line lies. The most likely injured ligament is the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL), which is situated in the intercondylar area.



Reference- Textbook of Orthopedics by John Ebnezar fourth edition Page no 248,249

questions.text: What is the cause of ankle sprains brought on by the forced inversion of a plantar-flexed foot?
questions.solution:
Ankle sprain due to forced inversion of a plantar flexed foot is due to injury to anterior talofibular ligament.

The lateral ligament complex, often the anterior tibiofibular ligament, is involved in more than 90% of ankle ligament injuries (twisted ankle or ankle sprain).

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? in case of an athletic teenage girl complains of anterior knee pain on climbing stairs and on getting up after prolonged sitting?
questions.solution:
• Chondromalacia Patellae is a condition where the cartilage on the undersurface of the patella (kneecap) becomes soft, frayed and damaged, leading to pain in the front of the knee.
  • This condition is commonly seen in young athletes, especially females, who engage in activities that involve repetitive bending of the knee such as running, jumping, or squatting.
  • The pain is usually worse when going up and down stairs or after prolonged sitting with the knee in bent position.
  • Treatment for chondromalacia patellae typically involves rest, physical therapy, and pain management, and in severe cases, surgery may be necessary.
  • Plica syndrome-When a fold in the synovial tissue (plica) becomes irritated and inflamed.It is caused by repetitive knee movements. Clinical features include pain at rest infront and inner side of knee.

Reference- Textbook of Orthopedics by John Ebnezar fourth edition Page no  426

questions.text: A six year old boy presented to the emergency department with a painful limb. Clinical examination reveals tenderness in the femoral triangle and some limitation of hip movements. An X-ray was done which was normal. What is the likely next course of action?
questions.solution:
• The next best step in this scenario would be to do ultrasound. 
  • The most likely diagnosis is transient synovitis of the hip, which is a self-limiting condition that can cause hip pain and limited movement in young children.
  • X-rays are often normal in cases of transient synovitis, so a normal X-ray does not rule out this diagnosis.
  • Ultrasonography is a non-invasive and effective imaging modality that can confirm the diagnosis of transient synovitis by showing fluid accumulation in the hip joint.

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 171

questions.text: Identify the injury and the surgical procedure done as shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
In the given image, the bones above and below the knee joint are fixed using a spanning external fixator for periarticular fracture. 
 

  • Indications: Spanning fixators are often used in cases of:

    • Complex fractures: Especially in cases where internal fixation (such as plates or screws) might not be sufficient or possible.
    • Open fractures: In situations where there is significant soft tissue damage or contamination.
    • Joint fractures: When fractures involve a joint and there is concern about preserving joint function during healing.
    • Distraction osteogenesis: In certain cases, spanning fixators are used for bone lengthening procedures.

questions.text: Identify the false statement about the dislocation of hip ?
questions.solution:
Nerve injury is more commonly associated with posterior dislocation of the hip rather than an anterior dislocation. questions.text:
Q2. A young boy presented with long standing knee pain without any definite history of injury. Which of the following is true based on the given image?

1. Superior pole patella fracture - cylindrical cast for 6 weeks
2. Patellar avulsion fracture - tension band wiring
3. Bipartite patella - obtain X-Ray of the other knee
4. Patellar avulsion fracture - interfragmentary screw fixation
questions.solution:
The young boy experiencing atraumatic knee pain with a frontal and a skyline view radiograph of the knee joint showing a smooth discontinuity with well-corticated borders is suggestive of an unfused accessory ossification center (Bipartite patella : two-part patella).

  • It usually is asymptomatic and is noted incidentally, however pain, when present, can be caused by overuse (such as in a cyclist or climber).
  • A fracture line running obliquely across the superolateral corner of the patella should not be confused with the smooth, regular line of a (normal) bipartite patella.
  • Checking the opposite knee is often the next step in the evaluation of such patients as bipartite patella is often bilateral.
  • Thus, this can be differentiated from superior pole patella fractures or avulsion fractures, which will have ragged margins. 
Reference: Pan T, Hennrikus W. Symptomatic Bipartite Patella in Adults Treated With Open Excision: Outcomes and Management. Cureus. 2022 Jul 9;14(7):e26705. doi: 10.7759/cureus.26705. PMID: 35959180; PMCID: PMC9359909.

Q4. A 20-year old male presented with shortening of left limb with multiple swellings in the limb and multiple skin lesions with irregular marking. X-Ray of the pelvis is as shown below. What is the diagnosis?

3. Osteochondroma

questions.text: The below image is of a femur bone. Which of the following muscles is attached to the structure marked
questions.solution:
The structure marked is the lesser trochanter, where the iliopsoas muscle is attached.



The iliopsoas consists of the psoas major and the iliacus muscles. These muscles originate from the lumbar spine and the inner surfaceof the ilium, respectively, and insert on the lesser trochanter. The primary function of the iliopsoas is flexion of the hip.

questions.text: A young male who had a road traffic accident is brought to the emergency department. His left leg is shortened, internally rotated, and adducted. On examination, femoral artery pulsation is not felt. A plain radiograph of his hip was taken which is shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario described is indicative of a posterior hip dislocation. In this condition, the affected leg is typically positioned in flexion, adduction, and internal rotation. Posterior hip dislocation is the most common type, accounting for approximately 80% of all hip dislocations, and is often associated with dashboard injuries.

Key features of posterior hip dislocation include:

Deformity: The leg will present with flexion, adduction, and internal rotation.

Radiological Findings:

The femoral head appears positioned above and behind the acetabulum.
The femoral head may look smaller than normal due to its displaced position.
The lesser trochanter is often not visible due to the internal rotation of the thigh.
Fractures of the femoral head and posterior acetabular wall may also be observed.
These clinical and radiological characteristics are essential for the diagnosis and management of posterior hip dislocation.

questions.text: What is the best line of management for a patient above 65 years of age presenting with intracapsular neck of femur fracture?
questions.solution:
• In patients over 65 years old with an intracapsular neck of femur fracture and a normal hip otherwise, hemiarthroplasty is the standard management approach.
  • Reduction and fixation of fractures in the elderly patient is not recommended due to the associated high rates of subsequent reoperation, non-union and osteonecrosis of the femoral head.
Reference: Essential Orthopedics, J. Maheshwari, 5th Edition, Page No 135.

questions.text: 75y old female came to the ortho OPD was diagnosed with and undisplaced Extra Capsular neck of femur Fracture. What is the best line of management?
questions.solution:
• Intertrochantric fracture is the most common Extra Capsular Fracture.
  • Dynamic Hip screw is the management of Undisplaced Intertrochantric fractures.
  • Proximal Femoral nails are used for displaced intertrochantric fractures.


Reference: Apley & Solomon's Concise System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th Edition, Page No 890.

questions.text: 27y old female presented with proximal one third fracture of shaft of femur. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
• Closed intramedullary nailing with interlocking screws is the preferred treatment of femoral shaft fractures.
  • Newer Techniques using Gross Kempf nails are used to prevent rotation of fractured fractured fragments and telescoping of the implant.
  • Conservating management is rarely done these days for femoral shaft fractures.
Reference: Apley & Solomon's Concise System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th Edition, Page No 899-902.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the OPD with the following deformity. Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
Diagnosis of Genu Valgum in Children
The provided X-ray of a child shows genu valgum, characterized by knees that are abnormally approximated, divergent ankles, and increased distances between the malleoli.


A normal knee typically has a physiological outward deviation (valgum) of 5-7 degrees. An increase in this angle leads to genu valgum, commonly known as knock knees, where the knees are closer together while the ankles diverge.

The intermalleolar distance—the measurement between the medial malleoli while standing with the medial femoral condyles touching—is a useful metric for assessing genu valgum. A distance greater than 8 cm is deemed pathological.

Children begin to develop physiological genu valgum around age 2, peaking between ages 3 and 4. By age 7, this condition generally resolves to a stable, slightly valgus position.

Other potential causes of genu valgum include:
Bilateral Genu Valgum: Conditions such as physiological genu valgum, skeletal dysplasia, metabolic bone diseases, osteoarthritis, and rheumatoid arthritis.
Unilateral Genu Valgum: Can arise from trauma, tumors, or infections.

Types of Knee Deformities
1. Genu Valgum (Valgus or Knock Knee): Characterized by knees that are abnormally close together and divergent ankles.
2. Genu Varum (Varus or Bow Knee): Features divergent knees with closely approximated ankles.
3. Windswept Deformity: An abnormal condition where one knee exhibits valgus deformity while the other displays varus.
4. Genu Recurvatum: Involves hyperextension at the knee joint, resulting in backward bending.

questions.text: An 80-year-old female patient was brought to the casualty with a history of slip and fall in the bathroom. She is having pain in the left hip and is unable to walk. She has no history of osteoarthritis. On examination, the left lower limb is shortened and externally rotated. X-ray findings are shown below. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette, along with the X-ray findings, suggests a fracture of the neck of the femur, and hemiarthroplasty is the most appropriate management for this patient.

Clinical Features of a Femoral Neck Fracture:
Painful movements of the hip joint
Shortening and external rotation of the affected limb
Tenderness in the hip area
Inability to perform active straight leg raising
Radiographic Features:
A plain radiograph of a femoral neck fracture may demonstrate the following characteristics:

A fracture line in the neck of the femur
External rotation of the femur, with the lesser trochanter appearing more prominent
Displacement of the greater trochanter
A break in the trabecular pattern
A disruption of Shenton's line

Management Guidelines:
1. For patients under 65 years:
If they present within 3 weeks, closed reduction with internal fixation using cancellous screws is indicated (Option A).
If they present after 3 weeks, assess the vascular supply of the femoral head using bone scanning or MRI:
If vascular, reconstructive options such as osteotomy (McMurray's or Pauwel's) (Option B) or procedures like Meyers' operation (Option C) may be considered.
If not vascular and the patient is young, a bipolar prosthesis (hemiarthroplasty) is preferred.
2. For patients over 65 years:
Hemiarthroplasty (using a bipolar prosthesis) is preferred if the acetabulum is normal (no osteoarthritis).
If there is significant osteoarthritis or acetabular involvement, a total hip replacement is recommended.
These management strategies aim to restore function and relieve pain while considering the patient's age and the timing of the presentation.

So,

Management choices:

  • Internal fixation with cancellous screws → preferred in young patients (<60 years) where preserving femoral head is important.

  • McMurray’s osteotomy → old procedure for non-union fracture neck femur, rarely used now.

  • Meyer's operation → muscle pedicle bone grafting, used in younger patients.

  • Hemiarthroplasty → treatment of choice in elderly patients with fracture neck of femur.

questions.text: A elderly male presented with a gait disorder showing the following sign. Which group of muscles are affected here?

questions.text: A 45 year old male waits a history of a fall from height and injury to his ankle presented with the following X-ray. Identify the following fracture
questions.solution:
A pilon fracture is a type of break that occurs at the bottom of the tibia (shinbone) and involves the weight-bearing surface of the ankle joint. With this type of injury, the fibula, is frequently broken as well. The fracture is characterized by fracture of the distal end of the tibia with or without distal fibula fracture, it is most commonly associated with comminution, intra-articular extension, and significant soft tissue injury A pilon fracture typically occurs as the result of a high-energy event, such as a car collision or fall from a height. Pilon fractures are often severe injuries that can permanently affect the ankle joint.
Pilon is the French word for "pestle" — an instrument used for crushing or pounding. In many pilon fractures, the bone may be crushed or split into several pieces due to the high-energy impact that caused the injury.
Apley & Solomon's System of Orthopaedics and Trauma 10th Edition • Page: 800

questions.text: Inflammation of which of the following bursa is called as Housemaid's knee?
questions.solution:
• The prepatellar bursa lies between the skin and the patella.

  • Repeated kneeling or pressure on the front of the knee can cause prepatellar bursitis, historically common among housemaids, hence the name.

  • Other bursae around the knee:

    • Infrapatellar bursa: below the patella; can cause “clergyman’s knee” when inflamed.

    • Subsartorial (anserine) bursa: medial aspect of the knee.

    • Suprapatellar bursa: above the patella, deep to quadriceps tendon.

5th edition Page no 410
