questions.text: A young male who had a road traffic accident is brought to the emergency department. His left leg is shortened, internally rotated, and adducted. On examination, femoral artery pulsation is not felt. A plain radiograph of his hip was taken which is shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In a posterior dislocation of the hip, the classical limb position is:

  • Shortened

  • Internally rotated

  • Adducted

This is the most common type of hip dislocation (over 90%) and often occurs due to dashboard injury in a road traffic accident, where the femoral head is forced out of the acetabulum posteriorly.

In contrast:

  • Anterior dislocation presents with the limb being abducted and externally rotated.

  • Fracture neck of femur usually causes external rotation and shortening.

  • Intertrochanteric fracture may also show external rotation, not internal.

Absence of femoral artery pulse may be due to vascular compression or injury, but this does not change the most likely diagnosis being posterior dislocation based on the classic limb positioning and trauma mechanism.


Reference:Apleys system of Orthopaedics and Fractures 10th edition page no 843

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
Syndactyly is a congenital malformation characterized by the fusion of fingers or toes due to failure of apoptosis during embryogenesis.

Types of Syndactyly

  • Simple: Fusion involves only soft tissue (skin and subcutaneous tissue).

  • Complex: Fusion includes bones and possibly nails.

  • Complete: Fusion extends along the full length of the digits.

  • Incomplete: Fusion involves only a part of the digit length.

    Associated Syndromes

Syndactyly may be isolated or part of a syndrome:

  • Apert Syndrome: Syndactyly + craniosynostosis

  • Poland Syndrome: Syndactyly + pectoralis muscle hypoplasia

  • Carpenter Syndrome, Smith-Lemli-Opitz, and others

    Differential Diagnosis

  • Symphalangism: Stiffness or fusion of interphalangeal joints.

  • Polydactyly: Extra digits (may co-exist).

  • Brachydactyly: Short digits.

  • Clinodactyly: Curved digits (often the fifth finger).
     


Reference:Apley and Solomon's system of Orthopaedics and Trauma 10th edition page no
404

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the hospital with complaints of pain and limping. The symptoms started 6 months back and gradually worsened. The child appears to be healthy with normal height and weight. On examination, there is mild wasting on the right side, abduction ( especially in flexion ), and internal rotation is limited due to pain. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation described — a 9-year-old boy with insidious onset limping and hip pain, restriction of abduction and internal rotation, and no systemic illness — is classic for Perthes disease, a form of avascular necrosis (AVN) of the femoral head in children.

In this condition, interruption of the blood supply to the capital femoral epiphysis causes necrosis of the bone. It typically affects boys aged 4–10 years, and initial symptoms are often subtle, such as painless limping or vague groin or thigh pain. As the disease progresses, hip movements — particularly abduction and internal rotation — become restricted due to pain and joint stiffness.

On radiographs, the disease progresses through several stages: the initial (necrotic) stage may show increased density of the femoral head, followed by a fragmentation stage with mixed sclerosis and lucency. The re-ossification stage shows gradual reformation of the epiphysis, and finally, the healed stage may reveal a normal or deformed (often mushroom-shaped) femoral head.

“Head at risk” signs predict poor outcomes, especially if seen in children above 6 years:

  • Lateral subluxation of the femoral head

  • Speckled calcification in the epiphysis

  • A horizontal growth plate

  • Gage's sign, which is a radiolucent V-shaped defect at the lateral epiphysis–metaphysis junction, indicating lateral extrusion and impending collapse.

Salter’s extrusion angle is a measurement that evaluates lateral displacement of the femoral head. An angle less than 50° indicates increased extrusion and a poorer prognosis.

Management depends on age and severity. In children younger than 6 with mild disease, conservative treatment — rest, physiotherapy, and activity restriction — usually suffices. In older children or those with more extensive involvement, surgical containment procedures, like femoral or pelvic osteotomy, may be needed to maintain the femoral head within the acetabulum and minimize long-term deformity.


Reference:Apleys System of orthopaedics and fractures 10th edition page no 537-540

questions.text: Following a spinal shock, the following reflex is the first to return:
questions.solution:
• The first reflex to disappear as well as return following spinal shock is bulbocavernous reflex ( S2S3S4 )
  • It is elicited by squeezing the glans penis or clitoris or by tapping the penile or clitoral shaft. The reflex causes a contraction of the bulbocavernosus muscle, which results in a downward movement of the anus and the base of the penis or clitoris.

questions.text: A patient complains of back pain that radiates to posterolateral leg, loss of medial hamstring reflex and decreased sensation along anterolateral leg, large toe web and dorsum of foot. What is the diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
• .The above clinical features are seen due to involvement of L5 nerve root which will be seen in L4-L5 disc prolapse.
  • Option A- L5-S1 disc prolapse will result in compression of S1 nerve root causing loss of ankle jerk and decreased sensation along lateral malleolus, lateral foot, heel and web of fourth and fifth toes.
  • Option C- L3-L4 disc prolapse will result in compression of L4 nerve root causing weakness of quadriceps muscle and decreased sensation along posterolateral leg, anterior knee, medial malleolus and medial foot.

choices.text: Decrease in movements and loss of sensation

questions.text: The loss of ligaments and joint receptors during hip replacement surgery will result in?
questions.solution:
he correct answer is 4. Decrease in movements and loss of sensation.

Explanation:

During hip replacement surgery, the removal of certain ligaments and joint receptors (like those involved in proprioception) can lead to a decrease in the ability to sense the position and movement of the hip joint. This loss of joint receptors can impair proprioception, which is the body's sense of the position and movement of the joint.

Though the joint may still function mechanically after the surgery, the person might experience a decrease in certain movements and a reduction in sensory feedback from the joint. While the prosthetic joint itself may not have the same sensory feedback as the natural joint, sensory abilities and joint movement can improve with rehabilitation.


Reference: Ganong's Review Of Medical physiology 26th Edition Page no 165

questions.text: Who is the most likely to develop spinal injury with symptoms but no radiological evidence?
questions.solution:
• Symptomatic spinal injury without any radiological evidence is most commonly seen in children.
  • Following trauma, computed tomography (CT) and plain radiographs which are the commonly used radiological investigations do not rule out spinal cord injury.
  • This is especially important for children because there is a condition known as SCIWORA (spinal cord injury without radiological abnormality), and the changes may only be detected on MRI.
  • Early (within 6 hours) administration of high dose methylprednisolone improves the outcome.

Reference- Textbook of Orthopedics by John Ebnezar fourth edition Page no 328

questions.text: After a total hip replacement 1 month ago, the patient had sudden onset chest pain and shortness of breath on the second postoperative day. Right ventricular enlargement and tricuspid regurgitation were detected by echocardiography. Which diagnosis is most likely

questions.text: The characteristics triad of Klippel-Feil syndrome does not include:
questions.solution:
• Klippel-Feil syndrome is a  disorder characterized by the fusion of two or more cervical vertebrae in the neck.
  • The fusion of these vertebrae can result in a short neck, limited neck movements, and a low hairline at the back of the head.
  • These three characteristics are known as the classic triad of Klippel-Feil syndrome
  • Elevated scapula, as it is not a part of the classic triad of Klippel-Feil syndrome.



Reference- https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK493157/

questions.text: Which of the following vertebral abnormalities has the lowest likelihood of congenital scoliosis progression:
questions.solution:
• A block vertebra is a congenital vertebral anomaly where two adjacent vertebrae are fused together. This anomaly is considered the most stable type of vertebral anomaly, and it has the least likelihood of causing spinal deformity or scoliosis.
  • The reason for this is that the fused vertebrae do not allow for any motion, so they cannot contribute to the development of a spinal curve.
  • Hemivertebra, wedge vertebra, and unilateral unsegmented bar with hemivertebra are all types of vertebral anomalies that can contribute to the development of scoliosis.


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 234

questions.text: A 45y old male came to the ER following a car accident with Quadriparesis, sphincter abnormalities, sensory level up to the upper border of the sternum, and a respiratory rate of 35/minutes. The lesion's most likely level is:
questions.solution:
• C4-C5 vertebrae are located in the cervical region of the spine and are responsible for innervation of the diaphragm, as well as the muscles of the shoulder and upper arm and also containing descending motor fibres innervating the lower limbs.
  • Injury at this level can cause quadriparesis, Bladder sphincter abnormalities, and a sensory level up to the upper border of the sternum, as well as respiratory distress due to involvement of the phrenic nerve.
 
  • Injury at the level of thoracic spine will produce paraparesis and not quadriparesis since the nerve fibers supplying upper limb muscles are derived from brachial plexus which receives its predominant contribution from cervical spinal nerves. 


Reference- Apley & Solomon's System of Orthopaedics and Trauma 10th Edition Page no 838

questions.text: Match with the image
questions.solution:
• Cobb's angle is the angle measured from the uppermost vertebra to the lowermost vertebra in a patient who has scoliosis.
  • It is measured on a radiograph and is used as a reliable clinical assessment of scoliosis.
  • The Ferguson angle is similar, but it is measured at the lumbosacral area of the spine. It is used to determine how deviated the spine is from a normal, straight position. The measurement of both angles can help doctor's diagnose and classify the severity of the patient's scoliosis.
  • The Böhler angle is the angle on a lateral foot radiograph between a line joining the highest point of the anterior process of the calcaneus and the highest point of the posterior articular facet, and a line joining the highest point of the posterior articular facet with the highest point of the calcaneal tuberosity
  •  A reduced Böhler angle can be seen in displaced intra-articular calcaneal fractures.
  • Baumann's angle, which is the angle formed in the AP view by the diaphyseal axis of the humerus and the physeal line of the capitellum, is used to assess varus or valgus alignment of the distal humerus.
 



Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 281,282

questions.text: A 42-year-old man finds it difficult to bend forward and experiences back stiffness. His CT scan picture is shown. What exactly is the diagnosis?

Clinical features:

Lower back discomfort and stiffness gradually start to appear.

The patient is usually awakened by pain in the early morning or late at night, and becomes better after going for a walk or after exercising.

On X-ray:

i. Squaring of vertebrae
ii. Loss of Lumbar lordosis
iii. Bridging osteophytes
Iv. Bamboo spine appearance

questions.text: A patient has reported having neck and back pain for the past month. The indicated beam is visible in:

questions.text: In which of the following situation is  biopsy not indicated in TB spine:
questions.solution:
Biopsy is indicated in TB spine in all except cold abscess without neurological compromise.
In cases of cold abscesses, particularly those caused by tuberculosis (TB) a biopsy may not be necessary if there are no neurological complications and the diagnosis is clear based on clinical presentation and imaging. 
  • Cold abscesses, especially when associated with TB, often have a characteristic clinical and radiological presentation.
  • If a cold abscess is strongly suspected based on factors like tuberculin skin testing, imaging  and patient history, a biopsy may not add significant diagnostic value.
  • Risk of Spread: TB cold abscesses are generally caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, and performing a biopsy can increase the risk of spreading the infection either locally or systemically.
  • Response to Empirical Treatment: In many cases of TB-related cold abscesses, physicians might start anti-tubercular therapy (ATT) based on clinical suspicion, and the abscess may resolve with medical management. If the patient responds well to ATT, there may be no need for a biopsy.
  • Lack of Neurological Complications: If there are no neurological complications, such as compression of nerves or the spinal cord, the urgency for invasive diagnostic procedures like biopsies is reduced. Neurological involvement might warrant further investigation to prevent long-term damage, but in its absence, conservative management is often preferred.
 

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 185
https://atm.amegroups.org/article/view/103385/html

questions.text: Scoliosis is present in the patient. Which test from the list below will you use to distinguish between congenital and postural scoliosis?
questions.solution:
• Test used to differentiate congenital and postural scoliosis is forward bending test.
  • The Adam forward bend test ,in which scoliosis disappears in case of non structural scoliosis when patient bent forwards, can be used to make a distinction between structural scoliosis or non-structural scoliosis of the cervical to lumbar spine.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old patient has been experiencing chronic low back pain and morning stiffness for the past two years.
There have been bilateral heel pains for the past six months. The patient's most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
• The most likely diagnosis is ankylosing spondylitis. 
  • Ankylosing spondylitis (less commonly known as Bechterew disease or Marie Strümpell disease) is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy, which results in fusion (ankylosis) of the spine and sacroiliac (SI) joints. 
  • It is strongly associated with HLA-B27. 
  • Bilateral heel pain is due to Enthesitis

questions.text: Back pain is being reported by a 60-year-old female who has previously experienced Cole's fracture. -2.6 is the DEXA Score.In regards to this patient's treatment, which of the following statements is false?
questions.solution:
• It is recommended that bisphosphonates be taken for at least three to five years, and in some cases, longer.
  • However, it is important to monitor the patient for any potential side effects, such as osteonecrosis of the jaw or atypical femur fractures.
Other options
  • Teriparatide is another drug used to treat osteoporosis. Teriparatide (PTH analog) is used in severe cases (T-score < -3.5 or multiple fractures) or when bisphosphonates are ineffective.
  • Calcium and vitamin D supplementation are also important in the treatment of osteoporosis to support bone health.
  • The recommended daily intake of calcium for adults over the age of 50 is 1200mg, and vitamin D supplementation is  recommended if the patient's levels are low.

questions.text:
A patient fell down from bicycle and started having pain around hip, shortening of limb and attitude
was flexion, adduction, Internal Rotation of Hip?
questions.solution:
• Shortening of the limb and flexion, adduction, and internal rotation (IR) of the hip are classic signs of a posterior hip dislocation.
  • In a posterior hip dislocation, the femoral head is displaced posteriorly from the acetabulum, causing the limb to appear shortened.

choices.text: Open reduction and repair of posterior wall acetabulum
Immediate closed reduction and check for hip stability.

questions.text: Following an RTA, a 14-year-old boy suffered severe hip discomfort due to a posterior hip dislocation. What is the ideal next step in management?
questions.solution:
1. Reduction of a dislocated hip is urgent because the longer the head is out, the greater the likelihood that it may become avascular. (Manipulate the hip when under a general anaesthetic.) 

If the acetabulum has a chip fracture, it typically heals when the head is reduced. In the following situations, open reduction may be necessary: 

  • when closed reduction is unsuccessful, typically in patients who present late; 
  • when an intra-articular loose fragment prevents accurate reduction;
  • when the acetabular fragment is large and originates from the weight-bearing portion of the acetabulum. The hip becomes unstable with such a fracture.

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 130

questions.text: On examination, there is weakness in the extension of the right great toe with no sensory impairment. An MRI of the lumbosacral spine will most likely reveal a prolapsed intervertebral disc at what level?
questions.solution:

  • Although most common site for a prolapsed intervertebral disc in the lumbosacral spine is the level L5-S1 followed by L4-L5 level. But since symptoms in given scenario suggests involvement of L5 nerve root hence answer should be L4-L5.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of intervertebral lumbar disc prolapse appears with acute back pain that has persisted for 10 days and urine incontinence. Fever or weight loss are not present in the past. What plausible diagnosis is there?
questions.solution:
• The symptoms of a person having a history of severe backache and urinary incontinence, along with an intervertebral lumbar disc prolapse, may be suggestive of a cauda equina syndrome, which is caused by compression  after L1-L2 level when the spinal cord ends.
  • This syndrome typically presents with lower limb weakness, absent reflexes, impaired sensation and urinary retention, causing overflow urinary incontinence.

questions.text: The Trendelenburg test is used to evaluate:
questions.solution:
• The Trendelenburg test is a physical examination maneuver used to evaluate the strength of the hip abductor muscles, specifically the gluteus medius muscle.
  • This muscle is responsible for stabilizing the pelvis when standing on one leg, which is important for maintaining balance during activities such as walking, running, and jumping.
  • During the Trendelenburg test, the patient is asked to stand on one leg while the examiner observes the position of the pelvis. If the hip abductor muscles are weak, the pelvis will drop on the side opposite to the standing leg, indicating a positive Trendelenburg sign.


   


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 348

questions.text: Most common pattern of involvement in Pott's spine?
questions.solution:
• Paradiscal is the most common pattern of involvement in Pott's spine. 
  • In paradisical lesions, the infection spreads via the arterial plexus. It starts from the anterior vertebral body adjacent to the end plate, involving the disc, and causes disc destruction.
  • With further progression, anterior wedging of the vertebra occurs with resultant kyphosis.

questions.text: Which test is being performed to detect fixed flexion deformity at hip?
questions.solution:
• Thomas test: The patient lies supine. The examiner flexes one hip maximally toward the chest. If the opposite hip lifts off the table, it indicates a fixed flexion deformity of that hip.

  • Ober's test: Assesses tightness of the iliotibial band.

  • Telescopic test: Used in developmental dysplasia of the hip to detect instability.

  • Trendelenburg test: Assesses hip abductor (gluteus medius) weakness.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man presented with low back pain that was radiating to his legs. On examination of the spine, a palpable step was felt in the lumbosacral region. The X-ray of the spine is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario described is suggestive of spondylolisthesis, defined as the anterior displacement of one vertebra over another.

Key Features:

  • Step-off Sign: A palpable discontinuity in the lumbosacral spine due to anterior slippage.

  • Radiographic Findings:

    • Beheaded Scottish Terrier Sign: Seen on oblique lumbar spine X-ray; indicates a pars interarticularis defect.

    • Grading of Slippage:

      • Grade I: 0–25%

      • Grade II: 26–50%

      • Grade III: 51–75%

      • Grade IV: 76–100%

      • Grade V: >100% (Spondyloptosis)

  • Etiology:

    • Most commonly due to spondylolysis (pars interarticularis defect), especially in adolescents.

    • May also result from congenital, traumatic, or degenerative causes.

  • Symptoms:

    • Chronic low back pain, exacerbated by extension or activity.

    • Radiculopathy or neurological deficits if nerve root compression is present.

  • Management:

    • Conservative: Physical therapy, NSAIDs, bracing, activity modification.

    • Surgical: Indicated for high-grade slips or persistent neurological symptoms; options include spinal fusion and decompression.

Note: The term "step-off sign" may also apply in other contexts such as Lisfranc injuries, referring to tarsometatarsal misalignment on imaging.


Reference:Apleys system of Orthopaedics and Fractures 10th edition page no 522
